title: Rclone sync doesn't sync directory mtimes
body:
# Info 
Rclone version: v1.69.0 Stable
OS: Linux Mint virginia 21.3 x86_64 (Linux 6.5.0-44-generic)

# Problem 
As per title, rclone doesn't seem to sync mtimes if these have changed in the destinantion. Directory syncing was merged as of v1.66, so it should be possible to keep modtime synced between two folders.

# Reproduction
```
$ ls -F
test/
$ tree -D ./test
[Jan 17 13:42]  test
├── [Aug  8  2023]  file8.txt
├── [Sep  9  2023]  file9.txt
├── [Jan 17  2022]  test_dir1
│   ├── [Jan  1  2023]  file1.txt
│   ├── [Feb  2  2023]  file2.txt
│   └── [Mar  3  2023]  file3.txt
├── [Dec 18  2020]  test_dir2
│   ├── [Apr  4  2023]  file4.txt
│   └── [May  5  2023]  file5.txt
└── [Dec  9  2018]  test_dir3
    ├── [Jun  6  2023]  file6.txt
    ├── [Jul  7  2023]  file7.txt
    └── [Dec  9  2018]  sub_dir
        └── [Dec  9  2018]  file10.txt

4 directories, 10 files
```

When I sync `./test` to `./test2` everything's working as expected
```
$ rclone sync ./test ./test2
$ tree -D ./test2
[Jan 17 15:17]  ./test2
├── [Aug  8  2023]  file8.txt
├── [Sep  9  2023]  file9.txt
├── [Jan 17  2022]  test_dir1
│   ├── [Jan  1  2023]  file1.txt
│   ├── [Feb  2  2023]  file2.txt
│   └── [Mar  3  2023]  file3.txt
├── [Dec 18  2020]  test_dir2
│   ├── [Apr  4  2023]  file4.txt
│   └── [May  5  2023]  file5.txt
└── [Dec  9  2018]  test_dir3
    ├── [Jun  6  2023]  file6.txt
    ├── [Jul  7  2023]  file7.txt
    └── [Dec  9  2018]  sub_dir
        └── [Dec  9  2018]  file10.txt

4 directories, 10 files
```

Now, suppose for some reason the timestamps in the destination change 
```
$ find ./test2 -exec touch -m {} +
$ tree -D test2
[Jan 17 15:18]  test2
├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file8.txt
├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file9.txt
├── [Jan 17 15:18]  test_dir1
│   ├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file1.txt
│   ├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file2.txt
│   └── [Jan 17 15:18]  file3.txt
├── [Jan 17 15:18]  test_dir2
│   ├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file4.txt
│   └── [Jan 17 15:18]  file5.txt
└── [Jan 17 15:18]  test_dir3
    ├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file6.txt
    ├── [Jan 17 15:18]  file7.txt
    └── [Jan 17 15:18]  sub_dir
        └── [Jan 17 15:18]  file10.txt

4 directories, 10 files
```

After I sync again with `rclone sync ./test ./test2`, I get
```
$ tree -D test2
[Jan 17 15:18]  test2
├── [Aug  8  2023]  file8.txt
├── [Sep  9  2023]  file9.txt
├── [Jan 17 15:18]  test_dir1
│   ├── [Jan  1  2023]  file1.txt
│   ├── [Feb  2  2023]  file2.txt
│   └── [Mar  3  2023]  file3.txt
├── [Jan 17 15:18]  test_dir2
│   ├── [Apr  4  2023]  file4.txt
│   └── [May  5  2023]  file5.txt
└── [Jan 17 15:18]  test_dir3
    ├── [Jun  6  2023]  file6.txt
    ├── [Jul  7  2023]  file7.txt
    └── [Jan 17 15:18]  sub_dir
        └── [Dec  9  2018]  file10.txt

4 directories, 10 files
```

In other words, **only file timestamps are synced**, folder timestamps are left as they were in the source.

# Expected behaviour
After a sync, both file and folder mtimes are updated to match the source folder.
